Born 21 December 1858 Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, USA

Died 24 January 1936 Westport, New York, USA

From c. 1879
Graduates from Harvard University and subsequently attends Harvard Law School; works at the banking firm Lee, Higginson & Co., Boston, Massachusetts, for several years; participates in expeditions to South America and Alaska with the United States Bureau of Fisheries

1891
Co-founds the Westport Mountain Spring Company in Westport, New York, which provides the water supply for the town

c. 1900–03
According to family lore, Lee designs the Westport Chair while vacationing at the family’s summer home on Lake Champlain in Westport

1904
Henry C. Bunnell (d. 1930), a carpenter from Westport and a hunting friend of Lee’s, adapts Lee’s design and patents a similar Westport Chair, which he produces in various versions until his death

PerMarkdown:
Born 29 August 1885 Chicago, Illinois, USA

Died 17 December 1961 New York City, New York, USA

1908
Graduates with a degree in mechanical engineering from Cornell University in Ithaca, New York

1913
Moves to Phoenix, Arizona

1927/28
Designs and constructs metal furniture for the Arizona Biltmore hotel in Phoenix; the hotel was designed by his brother, architect Albert Chase McArthur

1930
Establishes furniture company in Los Angeles, California, creates designs using tubular metal, including aluminium

1930–33
Clients include Hollywood movie stars Marlene Dietrich and Clark Gable; manufactures tubular metal chairs designed by architect Rudolf Schindler for Sardi’s, a restaurant in Los Angeles

1932
Applies for his first patent for joint construction of his aluminium furniture

1933–37
Following bankruptcy of his Los Angeles firm, McArthur opens a new business in Rome, New York

1936
Receives patent for aluminium joint construction from US Patent Office; opens office at One Park Avenue, New York City

1938
Factory moves to Bantam, Connecticut

1941–45
Designs and manufactures aluminium seating for 85% of United States military aircraft during World War II

1945–47
Designs seating for commercial aircraft

1948
Closes Warren McArthur Corporation

1948–61
Designs and manufactures institutional seating through his company Mayfair Industries in Irvington, New York, and later in Yonkers, New York

ca. 1951–66
A number of Warren McArthur designs are manufactured in Australia by National Art Metal Company (NAMCO)

Apprentice cabinetmaker in his father’s workshop in Koryčany

1922–26

Deputy director of the UP sales department and its Brno sales outlet

1948
UP is nationalized; Halabala heads a new research unit for the woodworking industry

1954–69
Teaching and research at the College of Forestry and Woodworking Technology in Zvolen, from 1955 as a tenured professor

PerMarkdown:
Born 6 October 1887 La Chaux-de-Fonds, Switzerland

Died 27 August 1965 Roquebrune-Cap-Martin, France

1902–07
Trains as an engraver and ornamental metalworker at the École d’Art in La Chaux-de-Fonds, after which he continues his education on Charles L’Eplattenier’s *Cours supérieur*

1906/07
First architectural project, the Villa Fallet in La Chaux-de-Fonds

1907–11
Study trips and work experience in Vienna, Paris (Atelier Auguste Perret) and Berlin (as an assistant to Peter Behrens)

1911
Travels through the Balkans and visits Istanbul, Athens, and Naples

1911–17
Teaches architecture and interior design at the École d’Art in La Chaux-de-Fonds

From 1911
Active as an architect and interior designer

1917
Moves to Paris and turns his attention to industrial production

1918
First purist paintings; publishes the manifesto *Après le cubisme* together with the painter Amédée Ozenfant

1920–25
Publishes the magazine *L’Esprit Nouveau* together with Ozenfant and Paul Dermée; adopts the pseudonym Le Corbusier

1922–40
Founds and runs an architectural office with Pierre Jeanneret

1923
Publishes *Vers une architecture* (Engl. *Towards an Architecture*)

1925
Pavillon de L’Esprit Nouveau at the *Exposition internationale des Arts décoratifs et industriels modernes* in Paris, destined to become a defining example of purist interior design

1927
Designs two houses for the Werkbund exhibition *Die Wohnung* in Stuttgart, Germany; publishes his *Five Points Towards a New Architecture*

1928
Co-founds the Congrès internationaux d’architecture moderne (CIAM)

1928/29
First tubular steel furniture designs with Pierre Jeanneret and Charlotte Perriand

1942–50
Develops the Modulor system for proportioning buildings, which he goes on to use extensively in his post-war work (e.g. Unité d’habitation, Marseille, 1945–52)

1952
Designs a line of wooden furniture for a holiday cabin in Roquebrune

1951–65
Urban planning of Chandigarh, the new capital of Punjab, India

Rüegg, Arthur, ‘Le Corbusier’, in Isabelle Rucki, and Dorothee Huber, eds, *Architektenlexikon der Schweiz 19./20. Jahrhundert* (Basel/Boston/Berlin: Birkhäuser, 1998), 338 ff.
Rüegg, Arthur, *Le Corbusier – Furniture and Interiors, 1905–1965* (Zurich: Scheidegger & Spiess, 2012), 399.
Vegesack, Alexander von, et al. eds, *Le Corbusier – The Art of Architecture*, exhibition catalogue, Vitra Design Museum (Weil am Rhein, 2007), 20–57 (biography compiled by Klaus Spechtenhauser and Claire Marie Rose).

Completes study of architecture at the Czech Technical University in Prague; collaboration with the workshop of Jan Koteřa

1910/11
Study trips to Germany, France, Italy, Denmark, and Sweden

Cinema interior at the Palais Koruna, Prague

Living room interior for Haus Zikmund in Brunn, Austria-Hungary (now Brno, Czech Republic)

Establishes his own studio in Prague

1918
Entrance of the Švanda Theatre, Prague

1921
Enters design for girl’s room in the first exhibition of the Czechoslovak Werkbund

1923/24
Double villa for the brothers Josef and Karel Čapek in Prague

1924/25
Urban covered arcade, Pardubitz*,* known today as the Machoňova Pasáz

1924–36
Modernization of the National Library in Prague

1926–29
Completion of the law faculty building initiated by Jan Kotěra (died 1923) for the Charles University in Prague

1928–38
City planner, State Regulatory Commission for the City of Prague

1931
Self-service restaurant in the Palais Koruna, Prague

1932–33
Villa Špišek in the Villa Colony Baba of the Czechoslovak Werkbund in Prague

1936
Gas station, Prague

1938
Self-service restaurant, Regent Street, London

1942
Co-founder of the Archive of Architecture at the National Technical Museum, Prague

after 1945
Planning officer, later a member of the Central Construction Office of the City of Prague

1948
Forced to give up his studio after the communist coup; imprisonment follows

1960
Political rehabilitation

Born 17 October 1905 Robbiate, Italy

1924–29
Studies architecture at the Politecnico di Milano in Milan

1929
Works in the office of Gio Ponti and Emilio Lancia; travels to the World’s Fair in Barcelona 1930–45 Completes interior architecture projects (apartments and exhibitions) and designs furniture at his own office in Milan

Shows his designs for exhibitions, interiors, and furniture at the Triennale di Milano

Focuses on designing residential and administrative buildings; also continues working on designs for exhibitions, interiors, and furniture for Cassina, Carlo Poggi, Knoll Associates, and others

Wins the gold medal at the IX Triennale di Milano for his Gala and Margherita rattan chairs

Builds the Pirovano youth hostel in Cervinia (Aosta), Italy

Redesigns the state art gallery in the Palazzo Bianco in Genoa; subsequently works on redesigning and expanding other museums in Genoa

Professor of architecture at the Istituto Universitario di Architettura di Venezia

Franca Helg joins Albini as a partner under the new company name Studio di Architettura Franco Albini e Franca Helg; from now on, all major construction and design projects are carried out in collaboration with Helg

1945/55
Teaches in the architecture faculty at the Politecnico di Torino

1955
The Luisa Chair wins the Compasso d’Oro

1957–61
Designs department store La Rinascente on the Piazza Fiume in Rome

1962–69
Develops design concepts for the stations of Milan’s underground line 1 and parts of line 2

1964–77
Professor of architecture at the Politecnico di Milano

Studies pre-medicine at Columbia University, New York City

Evening classes in sculpture at the Leonardo da Vinci Art School in New York City; assistant to sculptor Onorio Ruotolo

Assistant to the sculptor Constantin Brancusi, Paris

Studies traditional brush drawing in Beijing

Studies traditional Japanese pottery in Kyoto, Japan

First designs for large public projects (never realized)

Wall relief for the Mercado Abelardo Rodriguez in Mexico City, created under the supervision of Diego Rivera

Set and costume designs for the choreographer Martha Graham

Exhibits a chess table at *The Imagery of Chess* exhibition at the Julien Levy Gallery in New York City

Akari lamps made of traditional Japanese materials

First garden design for UNESCO Headquarters, Paris, inspired by traditional Japanese gardens

Studio in Long Island City, New York

Publishes his autobiography *A Sculptor’s World;* first retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art, New York City

Studio in Mure-cho on Shikoku, Japan

1985
Opening of the Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum in Long Island City (now the Noguchi Museum)

Opening of the Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum in Japan, in his former studio in Mure-cho

The Girard family moves from New York to Florence, Italy

Moves to Detroit

1949
Organizes the exhibition *For Modern Living* at the Detroit Institute of Art

Director of the new Textiles Division at the furniture manufacturer Herman Miller; in the period from 1952 to 1973, Girard will create more than 300 textile designs for Herman Miller

1953
Moves to Santa Fe, New Mexico

Interior design of the Miller House in Columbus, Indiana

1955
Commences work for the Georg Jensen company

1960
Design of the restaurant La Fonda del Sol, New York City

The Herman Miller shop Textiles & Objects opens in New York City; Alexander and Susan Girard establish the Girard Foundation in Santa Fe

3D mural for John Deere, Moline, Illinois

Design of new corporate identity for Braniff International airline

Design of the restaurant L’Etoile, New York City

The Girard Furniture Group is launched by Herman Miller

1971
Environmental Enrichment Panels for Herman Miller

1978
Donates his collection of folk art, encompassing over 100,000 objects, to the State of New Mexico

The exhibition *Multiple Visions: A Common Bond* opens in the Girard Wing of the Museum of International Folk Art in Santa Fe

1996
After the death of Alexander Girard (1993) and his wife Susan (1996) his estate is donated to the Vitra Design Museum

PerMarkdown:
Born 16 February 1856 Milan, Italy

Died April 1940 Molsheim, France

1856
Born as son of Giovanni Luigi Bugatti, a sculptor and successful constructor of firesides for Milanese villas

late-1870s
Studies architecture first at the Accademia di Brera, Milan, and then at the Académie des Beaux Arts, Paris

1880
Begins working as an architect in Milan, where he creates one of his first furniture designs: a bedroom furniture set as a wedding present for his sister for her marriage to painter Giovanni Segantini that year

before 1888
Establishes a workshop in Milan to manufacture furniture; unique wooden pieces often cladded with painted vellum result from this period

1888
Exhibits furniture for first time at the Fine Arts Fair in Milan; Bugatti furniture exhibited abroad for first time at the Italian Exhibition in London

1900
Awarded Silver Medal at the World’s Fair in Paris

1902
Receives a Gran Diploma d’Onore at the First International Exposition of Modern Decorative Arts in Turin, Italy, for his display of four furnished rooms

1904
Sells his Milan workshop to the De Vecchi firm, including licenses to manufacture all of the pieces produced there so far; moves to Paris where he begins working as a designer for the department stores Maison Dufayel and Au Bon Marché

1907
First exhibition of silverware at the gallery of foundry owner Adrien-Aurélien Hébrard, who also has Bugatti’s son Rembrandt under contract as a sculptor

1910
Moves to Pierrefonds near Compiègne and dedicates himself to painting and sculpting

1914–18
Serves as mayor of Pierrefonds

1935 or 1937
Moves to Molsheim, France, where his son Ettore owns the famous Bugatti car factory

Attends the k. k. Polytechnisches Institut in Vienna

Studies architecture at the Königliche Bauakademie in Berlin

1860–63
Studies architecture at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna while apprenticing as a bricklayer

1862–64
Assistant in architect Heinrich Förster’s studio

Competition designs for buildings including Berlin Cathedral and the Hamburg city hall, some of which were realized, and some of which were awarded prizes1882–83 Designs the office building of the Österreichische Länderbank and the apartment block at Stadiongasse 6–8 in Vienna

1886–88
First Villa Wagner at Hüttelbergstrasse 26 in Vienna

Volume 1 of the publication *Einige Skizzen, Projekte und ausgeführte Bauwerke,* (vol. 2 1897, vol. 3 1906, vol. 4 posthumously in 1922)

1894
Appointed professor of architecture at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna (retires in 1912); commissioned with the buildings for Vienna’s new Stadtbahn (city railway) in Vienna and a floodgate in Nussdorf

1896
Publication of *Moderne Architektur. Seinen Schülern ein Führer auf diesem Kunstgebiete* (publ. in English as *Architecture. A Guidebook for His Students to This Field of Art*); further editions in 1898 and 1902, and in 1914 as *Die Baukunst unserer Zeit*

1898/99
Apartment blocks on Wienzeile in Vienna; interior design for pied-à-terre at Köstlergasse 3 in Vienna

1899–1905
Member of the Vienna Secession

1904–06
Österreichische Postsparkasse, extension added 1910–12

1905–07
Church am Steinhof in Vienna

1909–12
Apartment blocks at Neustiftgasse/Döblergasse and second Villa Wagner at Hüttelbergstrasse 28 in Vienna

Co-founder of the Deutscher Werkbund

Administration building of I.G. Farben, Höchst near Frankfurt am Main

Terrace house for the Weißenhofsiedlung Stuttgart

Berolinahaus and Alexanderhaus office buildings at Alexanderplatz, Berlin

Head of the architecture studio at the Preußische Akademie der Künste, Berlin

Born 27 March 1886 Aachen, Germany

Died 17 August 1969 Chicago, Illinois, USA

1896–99
Attends the cathedral school in Aachen

1899–1901
Attends a trade school in Aachen; apprentices at building sites in Aachen

1901–05
Enrols in evening and Sunday courses in construction and drawing in Aachen; ; works as a draughtsman of stucco ornaments and in various architectural offices in Aachen

1907/08
Studies at the Unterrichtsanstalt am Kunstgewerbemuseum in Berlin under Bruno Paul

1908
First independent architectural project, Haus Riehl, in Potsdam, Germany

1908–12
Joins Peter Behrens’ architectural firm

From 1912
Freelance architect in Berlin, construction of several villas

1921/22
First avant-garde architectural design, a skyscraper at the Friedrichstraße station in Berlin (never built) and design studies, including a country house made from reinforced concrete

1925–27
Artistic director of the Weißenhofsiedlung Stuttgart, a part of the Deutscher Werkbund exhibition *Die Wohnung*, which includes the construction of a residential building with several model apartments

1926–32
Vice president of the Deutscher Werkbund

1926
Monument to Karl Liebknecht and Rosa Luxemburg, Berlin

1927
Patents the first cantilever tubular steel chairs MR 10 and MR 20; Café Samt und Seide for the exhibition *Die Mode der Dame* in Berlin with Lilly Reich

1928–30
Haus Tugendhat, including interior design (Tugendhat lounge chairs and Brno chair), Brno, Czechoslovakia

1929
German Pavilion for the World’s Fair in Barcelona, Spain, including interior design (such as the Barcelona Chair)

1930–33
Director of the Bauhaus in Dessau, Germany and in Berlin from 1932

1931
Signs contract with the firm Thonet to market their tubular steel furniture

1938
Emigrates to the US

1938
Professor at the department of architecture at the Armour Institute (renamed the Illinois Institute of Technology, or IIT, in 1940)

From 1939
Master plan and building designs for the IIT campus

1945–51
Farnsworth House, Plano, Illinois

1947
Retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in New York

1948–51
High-rise apartments at 860–880 Lake Shore Drive, Chicago

1954–58
Seagram Building, New York City (together with Philip Johnson)

1962–68
Neue Nationalgalerie, Berlin

Founds Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates (VSBA) with Denise Scott Brown after John Rauch left the firm

1972
Co-authors and publishes his *Learning from Las Vegas* with Denise Scott Brown and Steven Izenour

1978–84
Creates Venturi Collection, a series of nine laminated wood chairs, for Knoll International

1987–96
Design for Philadelphia Orchestra Hall (not realized)

1990
Institute for Economics at Princeton University

1985–91
Sainsbury Wing of the National Gallery, London

1991
Pritzker Architecture Prize, awarded by the Hyatt Foundation

1996
Works on renovation of an expansion of the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego, La Jolla, California

2000
Completes the campus centre of Princeton University

2007
Awarded the National Design Mind Award with Scott Brown by the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, New York City

2012
Venturi und Scott Brown retire from VSBA

*

PerMarkdown:
Born 21 May 1903 Wangen an der Aare, Switzerland

Died 20 October 1998 Zurich, Switzerland

1922–26
After one term studying mechanical engineering, embarks on architectural studies at ETH Zurich, taught by Karl Moser

1926–28
Works in the studio of Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret in Paris; supervises construction of their two houses in Stuttgart’s Weißenhofsiedlung; also responsible for their interior design, including a bed with tubular steel runners; meets Piet Mondrian

1928–30
Opens his own office in Gothenburg, Sweden, where he builds 200 homes and a vacation house

1930
Returns to Zurich

1932
Opens an office in Zurich; designs a bar trolley for the Wohnbedarf company

1933
Participates in the *Concours international du meilleur siège en aluminium* run by the Alliance Aluminium Cie., Paris, with an aluminium chair

1934–36
Edits the *Weiterbauen* supplement to the Swiss journal *Schweizerische Bauzeitung*

1936
Constructs two multi-family houses – known as the Doldertalhäuser – for Sigfried Giedion, designed in conjunction with Emil Roth and Marcel Breuer

1940
Publication of *Die Neue Architektur*, a book designed by Max Bill

1943–60
Editor of *Werk,* an art and architecture magazine

1949–56
Teaches in the United States, first at Washington University in St Louis, Missouri, then at Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts

1957–70
Professor of architectural design at ETH Zurich; simultaneously runs his own architecture office with international commissions

Roth, Alfred, *Die Neue Architektur: 1930–1940; dargestellt an 20 Beispielen* (Zurich: Verlag für Architektur Artemis, 2nd edn 1976).

Moos, Stanislaus von, ed., *Alfred Roth. Architect of Continuity – Architekt der Kontinuität* (Zurich: Waser, 1985).

1950
Opened his own architectural studio

1953–55
Built the chapel and auditorium for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge

Born 1796 Boppard, Germany

Died 1871 Vienna, Austria

Trained as a carpenter and cabinetmaker in Boppard

1819
Opened his own furniture workshop

1830
First experiments with laminated wood

1842
His workshop in Boppard was impounded; moved to Vienna; granted a five-year royal patent to produce bent laminated wood; employed in the workshop of the Viennese furniture producer List

1843
Created chairs for the Liechtenstein Palace

1849
Opened his own workshop in Vienna

1850
Designed chairs for the Daum café in Vienna

1851
Received a bronze medal at the London world’s fair for his furniture designs

1852
Opened a sales office in Vienna; received a second patent for bending laminated wood

1853
Transferred ownership of the company to his sons under the name Gebrüder Thonet

1855
Participated in the Paris world’s fair; first orders from overseas

1856
Established the first furniture plant in Korichan, Moravia; Austrian citizenship; granted the “patent for the solid bending of chairs and table legs”

1858
Closed down the Viennese workshop; opened a second sales office in Vienna; began producing chair “No. 14”

1862
Established a second factory in Bistritz, Czechoslovakia

1866
Set up a third plant in Gross-Ugrocs, Hungary

PerMarkdown:
Born 14 October 1886 Vienna, Austria-Hungary

Died 21 March 1958 Los Angeles, California, USA

1904–12
Studies architecture at the k. k. Technische Hochschule in Vienna and then at the Königliche Technische Hochschule in Berlin-Charlottenburg; works for the architecture office of Otto Rudolf Salvisberg in Berlin

1914
Travels to the USA and then to Japan; returns to the USA, where he remains following the outbreak of World War I; opens a shop for Japanese imports in New York City

1915/16
Set design for the Washington Square Players

1917–20
Extended stays in Vienna and Istanbul; returns to New York

1921
Opens the Frankl Galleries for the sale of European arts and crafts and his own furniture designs in New York

1925
Designs his first Skyscraper Furniture

1927–30
Lectures on modern interior design; publishes his first book *New Dimensions*; joins the American Union of Decorative Artists and Craftsmen (AUDAC ); is actively involved in the push for more rigorous copyright laws

1934
Takes part in the exhibition *Miracles of Chemistry: New Discoveries for Industry and the Home*, Newark Museum, New Jersey, to which he contributes a living-room interior; moves to Los Angeles and reopens the Frankl Galleries there; his clients later included Hollywood stars such as Charlie Chaplin and Alfred Hitchcock

1936
Travels to Japan; designs rattan furniture

From 1939
Serial furniture for the manufacturer Brown-Saltman, Los Angeles

From 1945
Closes salesrooms and focusses on serial furniture design with series for J.S. Ford, Johnson & Co., Grand Rapids, Michigan

Frankl, Paul T., *Autobiography* (Los Angeles: DoppelHouse Press, 2013).

Long, Christopher, ‘The New American Interior: Paul T. Frankl in New York, 1914–1917’, *Studies in the Decorative Arts*, 9.2 (Spring/Summer 2002), 2–32.

Born 5 November 1896 Kauernick, Prussia

Died 8 November 1944 Berlin, Germany

1918–20
Studies architecture at the Technische Hochschule in Danzig (now Gdansk)

1920
Studies painting and drawing in Dresden

1921–25
Studies at the Staatliches Bauhaus in Weimar, from 1922 as an apprentice in the cabinetmaker’s workshop

1924
Becomes an *Etatgeselle* (employed apprentice) in the Bauhaus workshop

1925/26
Takes charge of the cabinetmaker’s workshop in Weimar

1926
Furniture designs and interiors for a children’s home in the district of Neuruppin

1926–30
Heads the cabinetmaking department at the Staatliche Hochschule für Handwerk und Baukunst (a.k.a. Staatliche Bauhochschule Weimar)

1927
Designs *Typenmöbel*, standardized furniture for an apartment in Mies van der Rohe’s block in the Weißenhofsiedlung Stuttgart; takes part in the *Der Stuhl* exhibition in Stuttgart; designs furniture for the university school in Jena

1928
Furnishes a model apartment with *Typenmöbel* furniture for the *Bauen und Wohnen* exhibition in Berlin

1930/31
Designs for furniture manufacturers including Scheidemantel in Weimar, Cebaso-Stahlmöbel in Ohrdruf, Bamberger in Lichtenfels, and F. Kerber in Coburg; presents his designs in *Möbelbau in Holz, Rohr und Stahl* (1931)

1931–33
Artistic director of the cabinetmaker’s workshop in the Werkstätten der Stadt Halle / Staatlich-städtische Kunstgewerbeschule Burg Giebichenstein in Halle/Saale

1936
Works for the Amt für Schönheit der Arbeit (office for the beauty of work), Hanover as an advisor and administrative officer responsible for factory design

1939
Advisor to the Reichskammer der bildenden Künste, Berlin

Born 18 February 1899 Alexandria, Egypt

Died 12 April 1967 Barnet, Great Britain

1915–16
Trains at the engineering firm Ruston, Proctor & Co. in Lincoln, Great Britain

mid-1920s–1933
Works as a manager at Marconi’s Wireless Telegraph Company in London

late 1920s
Designs his first pieces of furniture for his own residence

1931
Establishes the company Makers of Simple Furniture in London with his wife Marjorie Amy Butcher while continuing to work for Marconi’s

1933
Works exclusively as a furniture designer; meets Jack Pritchard of the Isokon Furniture Company

1934
Issues illustrated catalogue sheets for the first time to market his furniture designs; participates in a furniture exhibition in Bristol, Great Britain for the first time

1936
Participates in the *Exhibition of Everyday Things*, organized by the Royal Institute of British Architects in London, where he shows, amongst others, his Bent Plywood Armchair, designed in 1933

1940
Makers of Simple Furniture closes due to the shortage of plywood during World War II

1943
Establishes Gerald Summers Ltd. in London, selling ball- and roller-bearings

*
*Deese, Martha, ‘Gerald Summers and the Makers of Simple Furniture’, *Journal of Design History*, 5.3 (1992), 183–205.**

Born 23 March 1886 Basel, Switzerland

Died 3 August 1958 Zurich, Switzerland

1901–03
Trains as a carpenter in Basel

1903–05
Trains as a furniture designer in Basel

1908
Apprentice ornamental metalworker in a metalwork studio in Basel

1909
Designer in a furniture factory in Freiburg im Breisgau, Germany

Works as an independent designer of interiors, commercial art and furniture for artisanship and industry in Munich, for the graphic artist Ludwig Hohlwein and others

Works in the Munich architectural office of Ino A. Campbell

1916
Assistant teacher in the class for interior design at the Kunstgewerbeschule in Zurich; joins the Schweizerischer Werkbund

1918–51
Heads the class for interior design at the Kunstgewerbeschule in Zurich

Designs a single room apartment for the exhibition *Das neue Heim* at the Kunstgewerbeschule in Zurich

Member of the Swiss group at the Deutscher Werkbund exhibition *Die Wohnung* at the Weißenhofsiedlung Stuttgart

1931
Participates in the home design exhibition at Werkbundsiedlung Neubühl, Zurich, with an interior design for the first five years of marriage; designs a bookshelf for Embru-Werke, Rüti, Switzerland

Designs products for P & W. Blattmann Metallwarenfabrik (MEWA), Wädenswil, Switzerland

1939
Participates in the Schweizerische Landesausstellung (Swiss national exhibition) in Zurich with a living room for a musical family

1950
Develops the geometrical puzzle Trigon

Born 25 June 1880 Plauen, Germany

Died 15 September 1945 Berlin, Germany

Trains as painter

From 1902
Lives and works as a student of Peter Behrens in Darmstadt

1902
Co-founds the Vereinte Kunstgewerbler Darmstadt (association of applied artists), in which he produces joint pottery, jewellery, metalwork, and embroidery designs; the organisation was disbanded in 1908

From 1903
Various designs for the porcelain manufacturers Rosenthal and Hutschenreuther, among them the Botticelli service and Donatello service (with Philipp Rosenthal)

1905
Moves to Hanover

1908
Designs an armchair and other furniture made of corrugated cardboard

1920s and 1930s
Works as a commercial artist in and around Hanover (for e.g. Vosswerke, Sarstedt, Kiehl & Schmal, and Herford)

1936
Takes part in the *Deutsche Werbegraphik* (German commercial graphic design) exhibition in Berlin

From 1938
Resident in Berlin; works as an architect for the Deutsche Akademie für Wohnungswesen, Berlin-Buch

1945
Dies in the Soviet military administration’s Special Camp No. 3 in Berlin-Hohenschönhausen

Works as a commercial artist in and around Hanover (for e.g. Vosswerke, Sarstedt, Kiehl & Schmal, and Herford)

1936
Takes part in the *Deutsche Werbegraphik* (German commercial graphic design) exhibition in Berlin

From 1938
Resident in Berlin; works as an architect for the Deutsche Akademie für Wohnungswesen, Berlin-Buch

1945
Dies in the Soviet military administration’s Special Camp No. 3 in Berlin-Hohenschönhausen

PerMarkdown:
Antoni Bonet
Born 2 June 1913 Barcelona, Spain
Died 13 September 1989 Barcelona, Spain

Juan Kurchan
Born 21 November 1913 Buenos Aires, Argentina
Died 3 November 1975 Buenos Aires, Argentina

Jorge Ferrari-Hardoy
Born 1914 Buenos Aires, Argentina
Died 1977 Buenos Aires, Argentina

1937–39
Ferrari-Hardoy (1939) and Kurchan (1937) each graduates with a degree in architecture from the University of Buenos Aires, Argentina; Bonet (1937) graduates with a degree from Barcelona School of Architecture in Barcelona, Spain

1938
The three architects work in Le Corbusier’s studio in Paris during which time he develops a new city plan for Buenos Aires (never executed); Bonet, Kurchan, and Ferrari-Hardoy design the B.K.F. chair

1939
The trio establish the firm Grupo Austral in Buenos Aires and publish a modernist manifesto entitled *Voluntad y Acción*

1940
The B.K.F. chair is manufactured in New York City for Artek-Pascoe; production is interrupted due to wartime material shortages

1943–46
The Grupo Austral designs housing using reinforced concrete in the Martinez district of greater Buenos Aires; Bonet designs the Solana del Mar hotel and restaurant in Punto Ballena, Uruguay

1947–50
The B.K.F. chair is manufactured by Knoll Associates in East Greenville, Pennsylvania, but also by several other manufacturers in the Unites States and worldwide

1950
Unable to protect their exclusive rights to the chair’s manufacture, Knoll discontinues production; the B.K.F. continues to be widely imitated and produced

Born 13 May 1891 Budapest, Austria-Hungary

Died 22 June 1964 Greenwich, Connecticut, USA

1916–19
Teaches history and geography in Budapest

1919
Leaves Hungary via Vienna and travels to Leipzig, Germany, where his wife Irene has a professional engagement as an opera singer

1922
Moves to Berlin, where he earns a living selling locks and fittings

1927–29
Managing director of the tubular steel furniture company Standard Möbel, founded in Berlin by Breuer and Lengyel

1929
Signs contract with Mart Stam to use Stam’s cantilevered chair designs); establishes his own furniture company, Deutsche Stahlmöbel (Desta); files a complaint against Thonet due to the latter’s infringement of his exclusive rights to the production of cantilevered chairs according to Stam’s construction principles

1932
Decision by the Imperial Court of Justice in Berlin in favour of Stam and Lorenz

1932–35
Transfers his rights to Desta’s product range to Thonet; works as a patent lawyer with Thonet

1934
Begins a co-operation with Hans Luckhardt to develop reclining chairs

1935–39
Works as entrepreneur and develops a global licensing system for chairs in Germany and abroad

1939
Business trip to the United States; the outbreak of World War II takes him by surprise; remains in the United States; continues working on the furniture and patent business; designs reclining chairs

1949
Takes on American citizenship

1954
Partnership with Peter Fletcher in utilization and development of reclining chairs

PerMarkdown:
Born August 9, 1878, Enniscorthy, Ireland

Died October 31, 1976, Paris, France

1900
Begins formal art training at the Slade School of Fine Art in London; many of her influences, including Kathleen Bruce and Jessie Gavin, can be traced back to the art circles she moves in during this period

1900
First visit to Paris

1901
Meets and starts to work in lacquer with D. Charles in London

1902
Continues her studies in Paris at the Académie Colarossi, then at the Académie Julian; presents a watercolour at the 120th Salon de la Société des artistes français at the Grand Palais in Paris

1904
Travels to northern Africa with childhood friend Evelyn Wyld; there, they spend time with Arab women in Morocco to learn weaving and the process of dyeing wool with natural colours

1906
Moves permanently to Paris

1907
Works with Japanese lacquer artist Seizo Sugawara

1909
Starts to produce designs for rugs and hand-knotted carpets

1910
Opens two workshops, one for lacquer works with Sugawara as her assistant, the other for carpet weaving in partnership with Wyld

1913
Shows her lacquer works at the 8th Salon de la sociète des artistes décorateurs; her work gains the attention of the fashion designer and collector Jacques Doucet, her first important patron

1919
Commissioned with her first full interior project including wall panelling, decor, lighting, and furniture for an apartment by Mathieu Lévy; develops “block screens”

1922
Opens her gallery, Galerie Jean Désert, at 217 Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré, Paris on 17 May

1923
Presents her design for a bedroom in Monte Carlo at the fourteenth Salon de la société des artistes décorateurs and gains the recognition of members of De Stijl

1926–29
Works with Romanian architect and town planner Jean Badovici on the design of house E 1027 at Roquebrune-Cap-Martin near Saint-Tropez, France

1927
Evelyn Wyld leaves Gray to establish a partnership with American Eyre de Lanux

1929
Founding member of the Union des artistes modernes

1930
Closes weaving atelier

1931–35
Designs her own house, Tempe a Pailla, near Menton, France

1937
Shows a holiday camp project at the World’s Fair in Paris, in Le Corbusier’s Pavillon des Temps Nouveaux

1954
Renovation and extension of her latest house, Lou Pérou, in Saint-Tropez

1972
Named Royal Designer for Industry by the British Society of Arts;first retrospective in London

Born 7 June 1868 Glasgow, Great Britain

1883–94
Attends evening classes at Glasgow School of Art

Trains as a draughtsman in the offices of the architect John Hutchison, Glasgow

Hired as a draughtsman by the architects Honeyman & Keppie, Glasgow

Travels to Italy; returns via Paris, Brussels, Antwerp, and London

Collaborates with Herbert MacNair and Frances and Margaret Macdonald, who as a group called The Four (or Glasgow Four) design furniture, graphic art, and metalwork

1896–1909
Designs a new building, complete with interior, for Glasgow School of Art; project built in two phases (1897–99 and 1907–09)

1896–1917
Designs interiors and furniture for Catherine Cranston’s tea rooms in Glasgow on Buchanan Street, Argyle Street, Ingram Street, and for the Willow Tea Rooms

Marries Margaret Macdonald; designs the room allocated to the Glasgow Four at the Eighth Secession Exhibition in Vienna

1901
Enters a design competition for the *Haus eines Kunstfreundes*

1902–04
Builds and furnishes Hill House in Helensburgh near Glasgow

1901–13
Partner of Honeyman, Keppie & Mackintosh

1915–23
Lives in London with his wife; designs home textiles for various manufacturers

1915–17
Interior design and architectural remodelling of the house at 78 Derngate, Northampton

1923–27
Moves with his wife to the south of France where he struggles to get by; Mackintosh paints watercolours that are exhibited in shows in Chicago, Illinois, and Paris

1927
Returns to London for treatment for cancer of the tongue

PerMarkdown:
Charles Eames
Born 17 June 1907 St. Louis, Missouri, USA
Died 21 August 1978 St. Louis, Missouri, USA

1925–1928
Studies architecture at Washington University, St. Louis, USA

1929–1938
Freelance work as architect in St. Louis, interrupted by long trips to Europe (1929) and Mexico (1933/34)

1938/39
Studies design and architecture at Cranbrook Academy in Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, USA

1939–1941
Lecturer in design at Cranbrook Academy

1940/41
Wins two first prizes for designs submitted jointly with Eero Saarinen to the MoMA competition *Organic Design in Home Furnishings*

Ray Eames
(Alexandra Bernice Kaiser)
Born 15 December 1912 Sacramento, California, USA
Died 21 August 1988 Los Angeles, California, USA

1933–1939
Studies art at the private art school headed by the German painter Hans Hofmann in New York City and Provincetown, Massachusetts

1940
Attends the weaving class at Cranbrook Academy

Charles & Ray Eames

1941
Marriage and move to Los Angeles

1941–1945
Experiments in three-dimensional moulding of plywood; development of a production process for plywood mouldings on an industrial scale; first practical application of the method in a leg splint for the U.S. Navy (1942, production by Plyformed Wood, Venice, California); starting in 1942 Ray Eames designs the cover of the magazine *Arts & Architecture*

1944–1949
Designs an extensive collection of plywood furniture

1946
Eames plywood furniture presented at MoMA; beginning of collaboration with the Herman Miller Furniture Company in Zeeland, Michigan, USA

1948–1953
Enters MoMA’s international *Low-Cost Furniture* competition with chairs made of sheet steel and sheet aluminium; thereafter develops the world’s first chairs with a shell made of plastic

1949
Building of the Eames House in Santa Monica, California, as Case Study House No. 8

1951–1953
Development of furniture made of wire

1956
Launch of the Lounge Chair

1958
Launch of the Aluminum Group after a development period of just one year; successive shifts of focus from furniture design to the production of photo series, films and exhibitions

1959
Participation in the *American National Exhibition* in Moscow where their work *Glimpses of the U.S.A.* is screened on several big screens at once

1960/61
Concept and realization of the touring exhibition *Mathematica* for IBM

1964/65
Design of the IBM Pavilion at the New York World’s Fair with Eero Saarinen

1973–1976
Concept and realization of the touring exhibition *The World of Franklin and Jefferson*

1978–1988
Ray Eames leaves the estate to the Library of Congress and the Vitra Design Museum

Wins two first prizes for designs submitted jointly with Eero Saarinen to the MoMA competition *Organic Design in Home Furnishings*

Ray Eames
(Alexandra Bernice Kaiser)
Born 15 December 1912 Sacramento, California, USA
Died 21 August 1988 Los Angeles, California, USA

1933–1939
Studies art at the private art school headed by the German painter Hans Hofmann in New York City and Provincetown, Massachusetts

1940
Attends the weaving class at Cranbrook Academy

Charles & Ray Eames

1941
Marriage and move to Los Angeles

1941–1945
Experiments in three-dimensional moulding of plywood; development of a production process for plywood mouldings on an industrial scale; first practical application of the method in a leg splint for the U.S. Navy (1942, production by Plyformed Wood, Venice, California); starting in 1942 Ray Eames designs the cover of the magazine *Arts & Architecture*

1944–1949
Designs an extensive collection of plywood furniture

1946
Eames plywood furniture presented at MoMA; beginning of collaboration with the Herman Miller Furniture Company in Zeeland, Michigan, USA

1948–1953
Enters MoMA’s international *Low-Cost Furniture* competition with chairs made of sheet steel and sheet aluminium; thereafter develops the world’s first chairs with a shell made of plastic

1949
Building of the Eames House in Santa Monica, California, as Case Study House No. 8

1951–1953
Development of furniture made of wire

1956
Launch of the Lounge Chair

1958
Launch of the Aluminum Group after a development period of just one year; successive shifts of focus from furniture design to the production of photo series, films and exhibitions

1959
Participation in the *American National Exhibition* in Moscow where their work *Glimpses of the U.S.A.* is screened on several big screens at once

1960/61
Concept and realization of the touring exhibition *Mathematica* for IBM

1964/65
Design of the IBM Pavilion at the New York World’s Fair with Eero Saarinen

1973–1976
Concept and realization of the touring exhibition *The World of Franklin and Jefferson*

1978–1988
Ray Eames leaves the estate to the Library of Congress and the Vitra Design Museum

Studies architecture at the Technische Hochschule Hanover and the Technische Hochschule Stuttgart

Diploma of architecture, studying under Paul Bonatz at the Technische Hochschule Stuttgart

Architect’s office in partnership with Bodo Rasch

His furniture is exhibited in the model homes designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Peter Behrens at the Werkbund exhibition *Die Wohnung* at the Weißenhofsiedlung in Stuttgart

Designs first ‘suspended houses’

With Bodo Rasch publishes books on furniture design: *Wie bauen?* (1927, 1928), *Der Stuhl* (1928), *Zu – Offen* (1929), and *Gefesselter Blick* (1930)

Takes part in the travelling exhibition *Der Stuhl* in Stuttgart, Frankfurt, and Berlin

Joins the Deutsche Werkbund; freelance architect in Berlin

Moves to Wuppertal where he continues working as a freelance architect

Collaborates with Carl and Oskar Schlemmer and Willi Baumeister on further projects at Kurt Herberts’ paint lab in Elberfeld near Wuppertal

Hosts numerous exhibitions in his Studio für Neue Kunst in Elberfeld

Continues designing ‘suspended houses’ for various projects and competitions

His theory of architecture is published in London as *Some Roots of Modern Architecture*

Born 5 August 1899 Purmerend, Netherlands

Died 23 February 1986 Goldach, Switzerland

1917–19
Drawing lessons in Amsterdam

1919–22
Works in the office of the architect Marinus Jan Granpré Molière in Rotterdam, Netherlands

1922/23
Works for Max Taut and Hans Poelzig, among others, during a prolonged stay in Berlin

1923–25
Works for the architect Karl Moser in Zurich and for Johannes Itten in Thun, Switzerland

1924
Co-founder of the Swiss avant-garde magazine *ABC – Beiträge zum Bauen*

1926–28
Returns to Netherlands and works for Brinkman & Van de Vlugt at the Van Nelle factory in Rotterdam; designs three single-family dwellings for the Weißenhofsiedlung in Stuttgart; designs a chair without back legs

1928–30
Guest lecturer for urban planning at the Bauhaus in Dessau; moves to Frankfurt am Main; architect for Neues Frankfurt (projects included Hellerhof and a residence for Henry and Emma Budge-Heim)

1930–34
Extended stay in the Soviet Union; works with a group of architects centred around Ernst May to plan the new Soviet cities of Magnitogorsk and Makiivka

1934–48
Works as an architect in Amsterdam

1935
Joins the editorial board of *de 8 en Opbouw*

1936
Designs five terraced houses in south Amsterdam in collaboration with Lotte Beese and Willem van Tijen

1939–48
Director of the Institute of Applied Art in Amsterdam

1948–52
Moves to the Soviet Occupation Zone (later the GDR); director of the Hochschule für angewandte Kunst in Berlin-Weißensee; tries and fails to institute a degree course in industrial design

1953–66
Resumes work as an architect in Amsterdam

1966
Retires to Switzerland, moving frequently

Born 24 October 1903 Paris, France

Died 27 October 1999 Paris, France

1921–25
Studies interior design at the École de l’Union centrale des arts décoratifs in Paris

1926/27
*Coin de salon* and *Le Bar sous le toit* are well received at the Paris Salons

1927
Designs her first tubular steel furniture for her *Salle à manger* ; begins collaboration with Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret

1928/29
Development of a line of tubular steel furniture with Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, presented at the Salon d’automne 1929

1929
Founding member of the Union d’artistes modernes (UAM)

1931 and 1934
Travels to Russia

1932–35
Photographic studies of Art brut in collaboration with Jeanneret

1935
Participates in the World’s Fair in Brussels with the ensemble *La maison du jeune homme*

1936
Photocollage *La Grande Misère de Paris* (for the 3e Exposition de l’habitation in Paris)

1937
Leaves the Atelier Le Corbusier-Jeanneret; photomontages with Fernand Léger for the French Ministry of Agriculture pavilion at the World’s Fair in Paris

1937–40
Joint projects with Jeanneret and Jean Prouvé; Tables en forme (1938) and other items of wooden furniture

1940–42
Stay in Japan

1941
Exhibition *Sélection, tradition, création* at the Takashimaya department store in Tokyo

1946
Returns to France via French Indochina; occasional collaborations with Le Corbusier (e.g. the Unité d’habitation in Marseille and the Maison du Brésil in Paris)

1949
Founding member of the association Formes utiles

1953–55
Second stay in Japan

1955
Exhibition *Proposition d’une synthèse des arts*, Takashimaya department store, Tokyo

1956–74
Collaboration with the Galerie Steph Simon, Paris

1967–88
Designs the Savoyard winter sports resort in Les Arcs

1983
Chevalier de la Légion d’honneur

1993
Designs and builds a teahouse for UNESCO in Paris

PerMarkdown:
Born 17 August 1911 Varedo, Italy

Died 16 April 1985 Milan, Italy

1931–37
Studies architecture at the Politecnico di Milano in Milan

1933
Presents the project Casa Minima (Minimal House) at the V Triennale di Milano while still a student. Is awarded silver medal

1937
Joins his father’s furniture company, Atelier Varedo, as head of design and production

1939–45
Designs and builds the multi-generational family home Villa Borsani in Varedo, which later
houses his private archive and is opened to the public

1953
Relaunches the family business under the new name Tecno with his economist twin brother Fulgenzio

1954
The first Tecno collection, including Borsani’s D70 flexible sofa bed, makes its public debut at the X Triennale di Milano

1955
The D70 is followed by the adjustable reclining lounge chair P40, thus fully establishing Tecno’s reputation for designing technologically-innovative furniture

1963
T69 table with curved, cast aluminium legs

1968
The modular office furniture system Graphis, designed by Borsani and Eugenio Gerli, is unveiled at the XIV Triennale di Milano

1976
P126 executive swivel office chair with cast aluminium base and leather upholstery

1980
Completion of Borsani’s last design, a series of ashtrays (AB-AC1-AC2-PM)

1989
Tecno is awarded the Compasso d’Oro for longstanding achievements in the field of design

Bosoni, Giampiero, *Tecno design: L’eleganza discreta della tecnica* (Milan: Skira, 2011); Engl. trans. as *Tecno Design: The Discreet Elegance of Technology* (Milan: Skira, 2012).

His furniture is exhibited in the model homes designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Peter Behrens at the Werkbund exhibition *Die Wohnung* at the Weißenhofsiedlung in Stuttgart

1927/28
Designs first ‘suspended houses’

1927–30
With Heinz Rasch publishes books on furniture design: *Wie bauen?* (1927, 1928), *Der Stuhl* (1928), *Zu – Offen* (1929), and *Gefesselter Blick* (1930)

1928/29
Takes part in the exhibition *Der Stuhl* in Stuttgart, Frankfurt, Berlin

1931/32
Organizes the exhibition *ring neue werbegestalter* in Stuttgart

1933
Together with his wife, Hanne Bauer, publishes the avant-garde magazine *Zirkel*, the second edition of which is confiscated

1939–45
Serves at the front in France, captured and held as a prisoner of war

1946
Escapes to Stuttgart

1946–57
Builds a residential and office complex in the Oberaichener Wispelwald

1984
Solo exhibition in the Architekturgalerie Am Weißenhof in Stuttgart

Kuper, Marijke, and Mart van Schijndel, ‘Der Sitzgeist. Over het ontstaan van de Zigzagstoel’, *Jong Holland*, 3.2 (1987), 4–12.

Máčel, Otakar, and Marijke Kuper, ‘The Chairs of Heinz Rasch’, *Journal of Design History*, 6,1 (1993), 25–44.
Marzona, Egidio, *Brüder Rasch. Material, Konstruktion, Form* (Düsseldorf: Edition Marzona, 1981).

Born 2 August 1928 Berlin-Friedenau, Germany

1946
Studied painting and sculpture at the Berlin College of Visual Arts

1948
Studied aerodynamics in Paris; carried out futuristic studies for car and motorcycle magazines

1952–53
“High-speed” and material research for the Douglas aircraft company in California

1954
Returned to Europe; received the Goldene Rose award for a Fiat car-body; worked for Alfa-Romeo, Lancia, VW, and BMW

1972
Experimental design for Thyssen, Boeing, Rosenthal, Rockwell (NASA), Villeroy & Boch

Established a Colani Design Center in Japan

Moved to Japan

Professor emeritus at the University of Bremen

1990
Architectural projects in Japan and Thailand

First extensive Colani retrospective in Dortmund, Germany; previous exhibitions in Japan and Switzerland

Designed computer hardware for VOBIS

1995
Opened a Colani Design Center in Lünen, Germany

2003
Designs uniforms for the Hamburg police force; designs the airplane tt-62, designs the futuristic Speedster Shark vehicle

2004
Speaks at the World Economic Forum in Davos

2005
“Colani Back in Japan” exhibition at the Museum for Art and Design, Kyoto Institute of Technology

2007
Collects “Grand Prix du Design” from the International Automobile Festival at the Grand Palais in Paris; FX Lifetime Contribution Award, London, and participates in the “Translating Nature” exhibition, Design Museum, London

2008
Opens a design studio in Beihai, China

Born 25 March 1939 Stranda, Norway

1959–63 Studies design at the Bergen School of Applied Art (now Bergen Academy of Art and Design) in Bergen, Norway

1963/64
Studies design at the Norwegian National Academy of Craft and Art Industry (now part of the Oslo National Academy of the Arts) in Oslo

1965–70
Employed as an industrial designer at the Tandberg radio factory in Oslo

1967
Begins collaborating with the Norwegian furniture manufacturer Stokke in Ålesund

1970
Studies ergonomics at Folkwangschule für Gestaltung in Essen, Germany, on a scholarship from the Norwegian Design Centre; establishes business as a freelance designer in Oslo; designs the adjustable child’s chair Minimax for Stokke

1972
Adjustable high chair Tripp Trapp for Stokke

1975
First office chair Calypso for Håg in Røros

1979
Presents first chairs based on the Balans seating concept, conceived by Hans Christian Mengshoel, the Variable balans for Stokke and the G-chair for Rybo

1984
Office chair Capisco with a saddle-shaped seat for Håg

1985
Garden chairs for Stokke, a series of ‘seating sculptures’ which became icons of Scandinavian

postmodern design

1993
Sitti, an adjustable child’s chair for Stokke

1995–2003
Receives Classic Awards for Design Excellence from the Norwegian Design Council

for Tripp Trapp in 1995, for Capisco in 2001, and for Balans Vital in 2003

1999
Solo exhibition *Movement: Peter Opsvik* opens at the Museum of Decorative Arts and Design in

Ghent, Belgium

2000
Co-founds Design Without Borders with Norsk Form (the Foundation for Design and

Architecture in Norway) to provide design aid in developing countries

PerMarkdown:
Born 20 May 1932 Wiesbaden, Germany

1947/48 Two introductory semesters in interior design at the Handwerker- und Kunstgewerbeschule in Wiesbaden (from 1949: Werkkunstschule)

1948–51 Apprenticeship as a cabinetmaker in Kelkheim, which he completes with a journeyman’s license

1951–53 Studies interior architecture at the Werkkunstschule Wiesbaden, graduates with honours

1953–55 Works in the office of Frankfurt-based architect Otto Apel, collaborates with, among others, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill

1955–97 Works for the electronic appliances company Braun: first as an interior architect, after 1956 as a product designer; becomes Head of the Product Design Department in 1961 and Director of Product Design in 1968, Executive Director in 1988 and Executive Director Corporate Identity Affairs from 1995 onwards

1956 Together with Hans Gugelot, he designs the radio-phonograph SK 4, commonly called ‘Snow White’s Coffin’; author or co-author of more than 500 designs for Braun in the following decades

1957 Starts collaborating with furniture manufacturer Otto Zapf

1959 Establishes the company Vitsœ & Zapf (today: Vitsœ) together with Otto Zapf and Niels Wiese Vitsœ; since then, numerous designs for system furniture for the company, for example the lounge chair programme 601/602 (1960, MGE-1161-1), the 606 Universal Shelving System (1960, MGE-1220) and the 620 Chair Programme (1962, SGE-1001)

1970/71 Designs and realises his own home in Kronberg im Taunus

c. 1975 First formulation of the ideas that will become Rams’ *Ten Principles of Good Design* in later years

1980–83 Travelling exhibition *Design: Dieter Rams &* in different European cities

1981–97 Professor for industrial design at the Hochschule für bildende Künste in Hamburg

1987–98 President of the German Design Council

Since 2000 Several solo exhibitions as well as two publications on Rams’ work

2006 Designs a so-called ideal house for the International Furniture Fair Cologne

2007 Receives the Design Award of the Federal Republic of Germany for his life’s work as well as the Lucky Strike Designer Award

2012 Appointment as TUM Distinguished Affiliated Professor at the Technical University of Munich; receives the Moholy-Nagy Award of the Moholy-Nagy University of Art and Design, Budapest

2014 Compasso d’Oro for his life’s work

E-Mail from Britte Siepenkothen, Office Dieter Rams, to the editors, 25.10.2016.

Lovell, Sophie, *Dieter Rams. As Little Design as Possible* (London: Phaidon, 2011).

PerMarkdown:
Born 17 July 1889 Nantes, France

Died 6 June 1947 Nantes, France

1908
Finishes his training as a decorator at the École Bernard-Palissy in Paris; begins his career as workshop director for the furnishings and interior decoration company Maison Gouffé

1921
Carries out his first ocean liner decoration commission for the *Paris*; many others follow, among them the *Île-de-France* in 1927, the *Atlantique* in 1931 and the *Normandie* in 1935

1925
Shows a number of projects at the World’s Fair in Paris, including the Chambre de Mademoiselle of Une Ambassade Francaise pavilion, on which he had collaborated with Eric Bragge

1928
Succeeds Paul Follot as head of the Ateliers Pomone, the Bon Marché department store workshop; starts working with cleaner lines and using metal instead of the traditional material of wood

1930s
Begins his international career with projects including the Waldorf Astoria dining room in New York, the League of Nations amphitheatre in Geneva, Switzerland and the furnishing of the Mitsukoshi department stores in Tokyo

1935
Named professor in the industrial design atelier of the École nationale des arts décoratifs in Paris

1939
Completes his commission to furnish and decorate over 500 railway carriages for the International Sleeping Car Company

1946
Appointed director of the school at the Union centrale des arts décoratifs in Paris

Franzke, Jürgen, *Orient-Express. König der Züge* (Tümmel: Nürnberg, 1998).
Martin, Sylvie, and Richard Wittman, ‘The École Nationale des Arts Décoratifs in Paris: Architecture and the Applied Arts between the World Wars’, *Studies in the Decorative Arts*, 8.2 (Spring/Summer 2001), 77–104.

PerMarkdown:
Born 8 June 1867 Richland Center, Wisconsin, USA

Died 9 April 1959 Phoenix, Arizona, USA

1886/87
Enrolls for two semesters as a special student of civil engineering at the University of Wisconsin, Madison

1887
Moves to Chicago, Illinois; works for architectural firms

1888–93
Works in the office of Dankmar Adler and Louis Sullivan, Chicago

1889
Builds a house for himself in Oak Park, Illinois, which he later modifies and enlarges

1893
Founds his own practice as an architect in Chicago

c. 1895–1915
Designs numerous single-family dwellings known as Prairie Houses, most of them complete with interiors and furnishings

1902–06
Designs the Larkin Administration Building for the Larkin Company in Buffalo, New York, including interior and furnishings

1909/10
Travels to Europe; prepares a highly regarded monograph, the Wasmuth portfolio, entitled *Ausgeführte Bauten und Entwürfe von Frank Lloyd Wright* (Wasmuth Verlag, Berlin)

1911
Moves his home and business to Taliesin, an estate in Spring Green, Wisconsin, which he designed himself and rebuilds twice after fires in 1914 and 1925

1913–22
Several stays in Japan in connection with the building of the Imperial Hotel in Tokyo

1923/24
Textile Block Houses, Mayan art-inspired homes in California

1932
Founds the Taliesin Fellowship, a private school of architecture

1935
Fallingwater House for Edgar J. Kaufmann, Bear Run, Pennsylvania

1936
Headquarters and administration building of S. C. Johnson & Son Company, Racine, Wisconsin

1938
Taliesin West, a second branch of the Taliesin Fellowship, opens near Phoenix

1943–59
Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York City

Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation [website] <http://www.franklloydwright.org> accessed 02.01.2015.
Pfeiffer, Bruce Brooks, ‘A Selected Chronology of Frank Lloyd Wright’s Life and Work, 1867–1959’, in David G. De Long, ed., *Frank Lloyd Wright and the Living City* (Weil am Rhein: Vitra Design Museum, 1998) 312–325.

Born 1 June 1894 New York City, New York, USA

Died 16 June 1944 New York City, New York, USA

1913
Graduates from vocational high school

1913–28
Works as cartoonist and freelance illustrator

1922–24
Attends classes in art and design at the Art Students League of New York and the Grand Central School of Art in New York City

1927
Surveys contemporary furniture design in Europe; meets Marcel Breuer

1928–44
Runs an office in New York City where he designs furniture, interiors, clocks, and light fixtures

1930
The Heywood-Wakefield Furniture Company in Gardner, Massachusetts, mass-produces his first designs

1931
Attends Exposition Coloniale in Paris and 6th Deutsche Bauausstellung Berlin

First modern furniture for the Herman Miller Furniture Company in Zeeland, Michigan

Interiors and furnishings for the Design for Living House at the World’s Fair in Chicago, Illinois, featuring Herman Miller and Heywood-Wakefield furniture

Director of The Design Laboratory, a school of industrial design in New York City

Attends the World’s Fair in Paris

1939
Designs the Rohm and Haas Company’s exhibit at the New York World’s Fair, displaying his moulded Plexiglas chair prototype

1941
Paldao Living Dining Group for Herman Miller, including biomorphic tables and a desk

1942
First office furniture system, the Executive Office Group, for Herman Miller

1944
Founding member of the Society of Industrial Designers, New York City (now IDSA)

PerMarkdown:
Born 10 March 1867 Lyon, France

Died 20 May 1942 New York, New York, USA

1882–85
Enrols for drawing classes at the École nationale des arts décoratifs in Paris, then changes to architecture

1885
Continues his architectural studies under Gustave Raulin at the École des beaux-arts in Paris

1889
Designs the Pavillon de l’Électricité at the World’s Fair in Paris

1893
Completes the Hôtel Jassedé town house in Paris, designed in the Henry II style

1894–95
Travels to England, Scotland, and Belgium; visits the Hôtel Tassel in Brussels and meets its designer, Victor Horta, a pioneer of Art Nouveau

1894–98
Builds and furnishes the Castel Béranger town house in Paris; influenced by Horta, it is the first building in what was later called the *Style Guimard*

1899–1900
Castel Henriette, Sèvres, France (demolished in 1969)

c. 1899/1900–1904
Designs entrances for the Paris metro stations using prefabricated cast-iron components (installed until 1913); extends this system to furniture designs

1902–05
Builds and furnishes the Hôtel Nozal town house in Paris, for Léon Nozal (demolished in 1958)

Born 15 December 1870 Pirnitz (now Brtnice, Czech Republic), Austria-Hungary

Died 7 May 1956 Vienna, Austria

1887–91
Attends the construction department of the Staatsgewerbeschule Brünn in Austria-Hungary (now Brno, Czech Republic), where Adolf Loos was also enrolled

Studies architecture at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna, enrolling in the master class taught by Otto Wagner in 1894

Assistant in Wagner’s architecture office

Becomes a member of the newly founded Vienna Secession

Professor at the school of arts and crafts in Vienna, where he teaches in the departments of architecture, arts and crafts, metalwork, and enamelling

1903
Founds Wiener Werkstätte with Koloman Moser and Fritz Waerndorfer

Buildings and interiors with the Wiener Werkstätte include the Purkersdorf Sanatorium near Vienna, Palais Stoclet in Brussels, and the Cabaret Fledermaus in Vienna
1905
Leaves the Secession together with Klimt and other artists 
1908
Head planner for the Wiener Kunstschau

1912
Co-founder of the Österreichischer Werkbund

1914
Designs the Austria House for the Deutscher Werkbund exhibition in Cologne, Germany

1923–25
First contracts for housing developments for the municipality of Vienna

1925
Austrian pavilion at the World’s Fair in Paris

1932
Four terraced houses for the Werkbundsiedlung in Vienna; the Wiener Werkstätte disbands

1934
Austrian pavilion for the Venice Biennale

from 1938
Conversion of the German embassy in Vienna into the Haus der Wehrmacht

1949–54
Housing developments for the municipality of Vienna

Attends the School of Arts and Crafts in Vienna; joins architecture class taught by Josef Hoffmann from 1899

1899
Designs stand at the World’s Fair in Paris for the Viennese bentwood furniture manufacturer J. & J. Kohn; appointed head of the design department at J. & J. Kohn

1900
Fauteuil No. 715 wins the gold medal at the World’s Fair in Paris

1901
Interior designs published in the magazine *Innen-Dekoration*; rooms and furniture made by J. & J. Kohn displayed at the winter exhibition of the Austrian Museum of Art and Industry; J. & J. Kohn stand at the International Exhibition of Science, Art and Industry in Glasgow, Great Britain

1904
J. & J. Kohn stand at the World’s Fair in St. Louis, Missouri, USA

1906
J. & J. Kohn stand at the World’s Fair in Milan, Italy

1908
Stage for the garden theatre of the Wiener Kunstschau

1914–22
Works in the design department of Kohn-Mundus in Vienna

1922–28
Works in the design department of Thonet-Mundus in Vienna

Born 24 June 1888 Utrecht, Netherlands

Died 25 June 1964 Utrecht, Netherlands

1900–04
Trains as a cabinetmaker at his father’s workshop in Utrecht

1904–08
Takes evening classes in applied art and architecture

1904–17
Works at the studio of the jeweller C.J.A. Begeer in Utrecht

1917–24
Runs his own furniture workshop at Adriaen van Ostadelaan 25, Utrecht

1918–23
First furniture experiments, including the Red Blue Chair

1919
Becomes involved with the De Stijl movement

1923
Participates in the exhibition *Les Architectes du Groupe De Stijl*, Galerie L’Effort Moderne, Paris

1924
Builts the Rietveld Schröder House for Truus Schröder, the widow of a lawyer, in Utrecht; Gerard van de Groenekan, Rietveld’s former apprentice, takes over the furniture workshop in November

1925–33
Runs the architecture office Schröder en Rietveld in the Rietveld Schröder House, collaborating with Truus Schröder on some of the projects that he realises during that time

1928 Founding member of the Congrès internationaux d’architecture moderne (CIAM) in La Sarraz, Switzerland

1933–64
Runs the Architectenbureau Rietveld at Oudegracht 55 I, Utrecht (1943–45 barred from practising during the German occupation)

1944–55
Teaches architecture and design at different Dutch universities

1951–52
Designs and participates in the exhibition *De Stijl 1917–1928*, shown at the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam, the Venice Biennial, and the Museum of Modern Art, New York

1958
First retrospective at the Centraal Museum Utrecht

1961
Establishes the architectural partnership Rietveld, Van Dillen en Van Tricht

1964
Made an honorary member of the Royal Institute of Dutch Architects (BNA) and awarded an honorary doctorate by Technische Hogeschool Delft (now Delft University of Technology)

PerMarkdown:
Born 3 April 1863 Antwerp, Belgium

Died 25 October 1957 Zurich, Switzerland

1880–84
Studies painting at the Koninklijke Akademie voor Schone Kunsten, Antwerp

From 1886
Logo and book designs

1888
Admitted to the Brussels-based avant-garde group Les XX (also known as Les Vingt)

1890–93
First decorative art designs

1894
Abandons painting

1895/96
Designs a house for his own use, Bloemenwerf, including interior fittings, in Uccle near Brussels; thereafter designs numerous interiors for the art dealer Siegfried Bing, the art historian and journalist Julius Meier-Graefe, and others

1897
Founds the Société anonyme H. van de Velde decorating firm, based first at Bloemenwerf and then, from 1899, in a studio complex near Brussels

1898
Founds the Henry van de Velde G.m.b.H. Kunstwerkstätten workshops in Berlin (liquidated in 1902)

1900–02
Interior design of the Folkwang-Museum in Hagen, Germany (now the Osthaus Museum Hagen)

1901
Appointed arts and crafts advisor to Wilhelm Ernst, Grand Duke of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach

1902
Founds the Kunstgewerbliches Seminar in Weimar, Germany

1906–15
Teaches at the Großherzogliche Kunstgewerbeschule, Weimar, which was built after his own plans

1917
Moves to Switzerland, first to Clarens, later to Uttwil

1925–36
Professor of architecture at the University of Ghent, Belgium

1927–36
Director of the Institut supérieur des arts décoratifs (La Cambre), Brussels, which he founded

1937
Designs the Belgian pavilion at the World’s Fair in Paris

1936–38
Designs the Museum Kröller-Müller in Otterlo, Netherlands (initial planning 1919–22)

1938/39
Designs the Belgian pavilion at the World’s Fair in New York

1947
Moves to Oberägeri, Switzerland

Föhl, Thomas, ‘Henry van de Velde, Lebensdaten’ in Föhl, Thomas, and Sabine Walter, eds, *Henry van de Velde. Leidenschaft, Funktion und Schönheit und sein Beitrag zur europäischen Moderne*, exhibition catalogue, Neues Museum Weimar (Weimar: Weimarer Verlagsgesellschaft, 2013), 418–33.
Schulte, Birgit, and Klaus-Jürgen Sembach, eds, *Henry van de Velde. Ein europäischer Künstler seiner Zeit* (Cologne: Wienand, 1992), 19 ff.

Born 18 March 1891 Paris, France

Died 29 September 1982 Paris, France

1908–14
Studies architecture in Paris; internships in London and Frankfurt am Main, Germany

From 1921
Annual participation in the Salon des artistes décorateurs and in the Salon d’automne, starting with his *Coin de repos*, an elegant and space-saving living room design

1925
Member of the admission jury of the Société des artistes décorateurs for the *Exposition internationale des Arts décoratifs et industriels modernes*, Paris

1927–1932
Draft of first tubular steel furniture; commissions for private homes, including for the art dealer Léonce Rosenberg and the Aga Khan

1930
Co-founds the Union des artistes modernes (UAM)

1935
Chevalier de la Légion d’honneur (section Beaux-Arts), participates in the World’s Fair in Brussels

1936/37
Designs furniture for schools

1939
Architect and designer of the French contribution to the World’s Fair in New York City

1946, 1949, 1955
President of the UAM

1950–66
President of the association Formes utiles

1954, 1957, 1960
Architect of the French contribution to the X, XI and XII Triennale di Milano 

1956
Publishes *25 années UAM. 1933–1955*, Éditions du Salon des arts ménagers

1958
UAM membership is put on hold

1964, 1966
Member in various committees of the XIII and XIV Triennale di Milano 

1982
Leaves his archive to the Union centrale des arts décoratifs

PerMarkdown:
Born 4 August 4 1883 Bordeaux, France

Died 24 August 1950 New York City, New York, United States

From c. 1900
Classes in fine arts at the École des beaux-arts in Paris

c. 1903–14
Works as a tracer, later as the chief designer at Waring & Gillow in Paris, a British furniture and interior design firm

1919
Establishes Atelier Pierre Chareau in Paris to design furniture and interiors; presents his interior design for the apartment of Dr. Jean Dalsace at the Salon d’automne, Paris

1924
Opens La Boutique in Paris, a shop selling his own designs and furniture

1925
Acclaimed at the World’s Fair in Paris for his office/library and relaxation room in a French embassy building

1926
Commissioned with his first realised work as an architect, a clubhouse for the Beauvallon golf club in southern France; presents his first wood-and-wrought-iron furniture at the Salon d’automne

1931
Completes the Maison de Verre in Paris for Dr. Jean Dalsace

1929
Designs furniture, mainly from wrought iron, for the offices of *La Semaine à Paris*

1930
Joins the Union des artistes modernes (UAM)

1936
Designs ready-to-assemble school furniture

1940
Presents wooden furniture for a colonial soldier’s mess at the second Salon de la France d’outre-mer; leaves France to escape anti-Semitic persecution

1941
Settles in New York City

1942–44
Organizes exhibitions and conferences about French applied arts in New York City

from 1946
Organizes exhibitions as artistic advisor for the French cultural attaché

1947
Converts a military hut into a house and studio for the painter Robert Motherwell in East Hampton, New York

Cinqualbre, Olivier, ‘Un destin en pièces’, in *Pierre Chareau. Architecte, un art intérieur*, exhibition catalogue, Centre Pompidou (Paris, 1993) 13–33.

PerMarkdown:
Born 22 May 1902 Pécs, Hungary

Died 1 July 1981 New York City

1920–23
Completes an apprenticeship at the cabinetmaker’s workshop of the Staatliches Bauhaus in Weimar, Germany

1921
Designs his first pieces of furniture, including some for Walter Gropius’ Haus Sommerfeld in Berlin

1923
Presents his wooden furniture, including the Slatted Chair, at the first Bauhaus exhibition in Haus am Horn, Weimar

1925
Named a Jungmeister (‘young master’) by Bauhaus Dessau; develops the first of his tubular steel furniture, including the B 3 lounge chair; commissioned to furnish the new Bauhaus building in Dessau

1926 or 1927
Founds the firm Standard Möbel in Berlin to produce and distribute his tubular steel models

1928
Leaves Bauhaus when Gropius resigns as director of the school

1928–31
Works from his own office in Berlin; designs further tubular steel models such as the B 32 chair and numerous interiors

1932–34
Designs a collection of aluminium furniture including the 1094 lounger; contributes to constructing and furnishing the Doldertalhäuser in Zurich

1935
Emigrates to Great Britain

1935–37
Designs plywood furniture for the Isokon Furniture Company

1937
Emigrates to the USA; works in partnership with Gropius until 1941

1935–37
Works as professor in the Department of Architecture at the Harvard Graduate School of Design in Cambridge, Massachusetts

1946
Relocates his architectural office from Boston to New York City

1948/49
Designs a model home including complete interior design exhibited in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art, New York

1952–58
Participates in construction of the UNESCO building in Paris

1962
Italian firm Gavina re-releases the B 3 lounge chair, subsequently known as Wassily

1964–66
Designs the Whitney Museum of American Art, New York, marking the high point of his reputation as an architect; opens a branch of his office in Paris

1976
Retires for health reasons

Contract between the city of Dessau and Marcel Breuer, 01.04.1925 (Syracuse University Libraries, Marcel Breuer Papers, <http://breuer.syr.edu/xtf/view?docId=mets/4221.mets.xml;query=;brand=breuer> accessed 24.07.2015).
Droste, Magdalena, and Manfred Ludewig, *Marcel Breuer. Design* (Cologne: Benedikt Taschen Verlag, 1992).
Letter from Marcel Breuer to the Under-Secretary of State, Aliens Department, Home Office, Great Britain, 29.08.1935 (Syracuse University Libraries, Marcel Breuer Papers, <http://breuer.syr.edu/xtf/view?docId=mets/3621.mets.xml;query=;brand=breuer> accessed 24.07.2015).
Remmele, Mathias, and Alexander von Vegesack, eds, *Marcel Breuer – Design und Architektur*, exhibition catalogue, Vitra Design Museum (Weil am Rhein, 2003).

Born 1901 Paris, France

1916–21
Apprenticed to two metal craftsmen in Paris, and studied at the École Supérieure, Nancy

1923
Opened his own smithy in Nancy

1923–26
First furniture made of thin sheet steel

1929
Cofounder of Union des Artistes Modernes (UAM)

1930/31
Established the stock corporation Société des Ateliers Jean Prouvé

Became mayor of Nancy following the end of German occupation starting in 1947 opened Les Ateliers Jean Prouvé, a metal and aluminum processing plant in Maxéville (near Nancy) which manufactured steel girder constructions

1971
Headed the jury for the design of the Centre Georges Pompidou, Paris
